results.clause_text: This document is a Service Level Agreement between Northwestern IT (service provider) and the (customer), outlining the provisioning of IT services. The purpose of this agreement is to establish service expectations, identify provider and consumer responsibilities related to this service, specify how this service is supported, and clarify service charges.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: If the foundational principles outlined in this introductory clause are not adequately elaborated and defined in subsequent sections of the agreement, both the service provider and the customer face substantial business risks. These include protracted disputes over the quality, scope, and timely delivery of IT services due to ambiguous expectations and undefined performance metrics. There is a high likelihood of financial disputes arising from unclear service charges or unfulfilled service levels, potentially leading to revenue loss, unrecoverable costs, or contractual penalties. Operationally, a lack of clearly delineated responsibilities and support mechanisms can result in inefficiencies, service disruptions, and strained relationships. Ultimately, ignoring the need for detailed provisions that fulfill the purpose of this clause renders the entire Service Level Agreement vulnerable to unenforceability, exposing both parties to significant legal and commercial uncertainty.
results.suggested_correction: This Agreement constitutes a Service Level Agreement between Northwestern IT (the 'Provider') and [Customer Name] (the 'Customer') for the provisioning of IT services. The purpose of this Agreement is to establish the service expectations, identify the respective responsibilities of the Provider and the Customer related to such service, specify the support mechanisms for this service, and clarify the applicable service charges.
results.justification: This clause is an introductory statement identifying the document as a Service Level Agreement and outlining its overarching purpose: to establish service expectations, define responsibilities, specify support, and clarify charges. While crucial for setting the context of the entire agreement, this specific clause is declarative rather than prescriptive. It functions as an administrative declaration of intent, carrying minimal direct legal or commercial risk in isolation. The identified risk score of 1.0 reflects its purely administrative function, acknowledging that enforceability concerns and commercial exposure arise not from this clause itself, but from the potential failure of subsequent sections of the agreement to adequately detail the service expectations, quantifiable performance standards (KPIs), specific responsibilities, support mechanisms, and precise service charge structures that this introductory clause mandates. Without robust subsequent clauses fulfilling the purpose outlined here, the entire agreement would be exposed to significant ambiguity, potential disputes, and enforceability challenges, leading to financial and operational complications. However, this clause itself is well-balanced in its statement of purpose and provides a clear framework for the content that must follow.

results.clause_text: Northwestern IT (NUIT) agrees to provide Endpoint device management and support as a service to customer. NUIT will: provide • Device deployment – Procurement, Custom factory image loading including enterprise licensed common applications, asset tagging and labelling, pre-delivery and staging services, and system installation, system configuration and data migrations. Delivers and installs your fully integrated systems to customer designated user locations. • Secure endpoint management - pre-configuration of security solutions and installation of antivirus, data encryption and data backup solutions. Regular application of Operating system and application software patches. • Device Management - Agent monitoring to ensure proper tracking of device lifecycle • NUIT Service Desk - represents the entry point and first-touch support process for all hardware and software service-related requests. NUIT delivers a strategic, customized full-featured service desk that is driven by the goals of quality, value, and customer satisfaction. NUIT service desk is accountable to resolve, track, escalate and follow-up on all Endpoint systems related issues that affect customer productivity. • NUIT provides on-site Field Services support for endpoint systems, software, and peripherals support. We assist with installations, moves, adds and changes, as well as everyday hardware and peripheral support services. Authorized service delivery providers will be dispatched to your End User when hardware, software, or peripheral problems cannot be resolved remotely. • Disposition and redeployment– NUIT delivers efficient, secure and simple processes for data recoveries to disposals and refreshes. Ensures that system data is destroyed for security purposes. Disposal of Assets and manages Employee Purchase Programs.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring the current drafting weaknesses would expose Northwestern IT to substantial operational and financial risks. Without clear customer obligations, NUIT may face delays and inefficiencies due to an inability to secure necessary cooperation, impacting service delivery timelines and costs. The lack of a defined change control process means that any changes to customer requirements could unilaterally expand NUIT's scope of work without proper resource allocation or compensation, leading to significant cost overruns, resource depletion, and service quality degradation. Ambiguity regarding service exclusions invites scope creep and disputes over what services are implicitly covered, further straining resources. Crucially, the absence of quantifiable deliverables and acceptance criteria would make it exceedingly difficult for NUIT to demonstrate successful performance or for the customer to objectively evaluate it, potentially leading to unresolved disputes, eroded customer satisfaction, increased legal costs, and even contract termination for perceived non-performance, despite NUIT's efforts.
results.suggested_correction:
Northwestern IT (NUIT) shall provide Endpoint device management and support as a service to Customer. NUIT shall provide the following services, subject to Customer’s timely cooperation and provision of necessary access and information, and as further detailed in applicable Service Orders or Statements of Work (SOWs):
(a) Device deployment, including procurement, custom factory image loading (including enterprise licensed common applications), asset tagging and labelling, pre-delivery and staging services, system installation, system configuration, and data migrations. NUIT shall deliver and install fully integrated systems to Customer-designated user locations.
(b) Secure endpoint management, including pre-configuration of security solutions, installation of antivirus, data encryption, and data backup solutions. NUIT shall regularly apply Operating System and application software patches.
(c) Device Management, including agent monitoring to ensure proper tracking of device lifecycle.
(d) NUIT Service Desk support, which shall represent the entry point and first-touch support process for all hardware and software service-related requests. NUIT shall deliver a strategic, customized, full-featured service desk driven by the goals of quality, value, and customer satisfaction, and shall be accountable to resolve, track, escalate, and follow-up on all Endpoint systems related issues that affect Customer productivity.
(e) On-site Field Services support for endpoint systems, software, and peripherals. NUIT shall assist with installations, moves, adds, and changes, as well as everyday hardware and peripheral support services. Authorized service delivery providers shall be dispatched to Customer's End Users when hardware, software, or peripheral problems cannot be resolved remotely.
(f) Disposition and redeployment services, including efficient, secure, and simple processes for data recoveries to disposals and refreshes. NUIT shall ensure that system data is destroyed for security purposes, manage the disposal of assets, and manage Employee Purchase Programs.
Any changes to the scope of these services shall be mutually agreed upon in writing and processed in accordance with the change control procedures specified in the Agreement. Services not explicitly described herein or in an applicable Service Order or SOW are excluded from NUIT’s obligations under this clause.
results.justification: This clause comprehensively details the Endpoint device management and support services that Northwestern IT (NUIT) agrees to provide. It aligns well with a 'Scope of Services' golden clause, as it outlines specific deliverables and responsibilities across device deployment, secure endpoint management, service desk functions, on-site support, and disposition processes. However, despite its descriptive nature, the clause presents significant legal and commercial risks due to several material drafting weaknesses. The clause primarily defines NUIT’s responsibilities without clearly establishing corresponding obligations for the customer, creating an imbalance that could impede NUIT's ability to perform efficiently or lead to disputes over customer non-cooperation. A critical omission is the absence of any change control process, which is essential for managing an extensive and evolving service scope like IT endpoint management; without it, NUIT is exposed to uncontrolled scope creep and potential resource strain if service requirements change. Furthermore, the clause lacks explicit service exclusions, which can lead to ambiguities and assumptions about additional services being implicitly covered. Most significantly, while services are described, the clause fails to define concrete, quantifiable deliverables or clear acceptance criteria for each service component. This makes it challenging to ascertain and verify successful performance, introducing enforceability gaps and a high potential for disputes regarding service quality and completion. Consequently, the reconciled risk score is 6.0, reflecting significant enforceability gaps, an imbalance of obligations, and considerable operational exposure due to the absence of crucial contractual mechanisms.

results.clause_text: The period of this agreement is September 1, 2019 through August 30, 2020. Each year, this agreement will automatically extend for one calendar year unless it is modified or terminated as described in this document.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring the current drafting may lead to automatic renewals without sufficient time or opportunity for either party to opt out, potentially binding the party to unintended financial commitments or operational obligations for additional one-year terms. This could result in continued payment for services no longer needed or desired, or the inability to switch vendors or renegotiate terms in a timely manner, creating unforeseen costs and operational inflexibility.
results.suggested_correction: The initial term of this agreement shall commence on September 1, 2019 and shall conclude on August 30, 2020. Thereafter, this agreement shall automatically extend for successive one-year periods unless either party provides written notice of non-renewal to the other party at least ninety (90) days prior to the end of the then-current term, or unless this agreement is otherwise modified or terminated as described in this agreement.
results.justification: This clause defines the initial contract term and includes an automatic annual renewal provision. While the initial term is clearly stated, the mechanism for automatic extension presents a notable commercial and legal risk. The clause defers to other parts of the document for modification or termination, but critically, it lacks an explicit non-renewal notice period within its own scope for preventing the automatic extension. This absence creates a significant practical imbalance and potential for unforeseen financial or operational commitments. Parties may inadvertently miss an implicit or generalized termination window elsewhere in the agreement, resulting in an automatic extension that binds them for another year against their current commercial interest. The risk score of 6.0 reflects this potential for significant enforceability gaps regarding practical non-renewal, leading to moderate commercial exposure due to potentially unwanted, prolonged contractual obligations.

results.clause_text: Maintenance of services provided in this agreement will be conducted in accordance with established NUIT Change Management practices, and will occur during scheduled service maintenance windows. Emergency maintenance, in response to service outages, may occur with no advanced notice to service consumers. Maintenance or outages of other, underlying or integrated, services may impact the services provided in this agreement. Notification of service maintenance and outages is available at: Service Status (https://service-status.northwestern.edu/). Information on how to subscribe to email service alerts can be found at: https://service-status.northwestern.edu/
results.business_risk_if_ignored: If this clause is left uncorrected, the service consumer faces a high risk of operational disruption, financial loss, and potential reputational damage due to unexpected service outages. The provider's ability to conduct emergency maintenance with no advance notice, coupled with disclaiming impact from underlying services, places the full burden of service continuity risk on the consumer. The requirement for consumers to proactively monitor a status page or subscribe to alerts for critical service information creates an unreasonable operational overhead and a passive notification mechanism, leading to reactive rather than proactive awareness of service interruptions. This imbalance could lead to disputes over service availability, hinder the consumer's ability to plan for downtime, and potentially cause breaches of their own commitments to stakeholders.
results.suggested_correction: Maintenance of services provided in this agreement shall be conducted in accordance with established NUIT Change Management practices, and shall occur during scheduled service maintenance windows. Emergency maintenance, in response to service outages, may occur without prior notice to service consumers, but NUIT shall provide notification as soon as reasonably practicable. Maintenance or outages of other, underlying or integrated, services may impact the services provided in this agreement; NUIT shall use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate such impacts. NUIT shall provide notification of service maintenance and outages via the Service Status page (https://service-status.northwestern.edu/) and through email alerts for which subscription information is available at https://service-status.northwestern.edu/.
results.justification: The clause unilaterally defines the conditions and procedures for service interruptions due to maintenance and outages, placing significant and imbalanced risk on the service consumer. It directly impacts service availability, a core component of Service Levels, without adequate commitment from the provider. Specifically, the provision allowing emergency maintenance with no advanced notice creates critical operational unpredictability for the consumer. Furthermore, the clause states that outages of underlying services may impact the provided services, effectively disclaiming provider responsibility for such dependencies without any commitment to mitigation. The notification mechanism relies on the consumer proactively monitoring a status page or subscribing to alerts, rather than establishing a direct, timely communication obligation on the provider. This shifts the burden of service continuity awareness entirely to the consumer, which is commercially unreasonable for critical services. These elements collectively represent significant enforceability gaps regarding the provider's commitment to service continuity and an imbalance of obligations, leading to a high operational and financial exposure for the service consumer. The reconciled risk score of 7.5 reflects these substantial concerns regarding the unilateral nature of the terms, the lack of firm provider commitments, and the disproportionate burden placed on the service consumer, which could lead to significant unnotified disruptions.

results.clause_text: The following list specifies responsibilities of NUIT related to providing the service set forth in this agreement. Northwestern IT will be responsible for the following: Workstations (desktop and laptop computers) • Build workstations Install one of NUIT approved computer images o  Dual booting or machines with multiple operating systems will be assessed and approved by the Technology Support Services Director on a case by case basis based on business, research or teaching need. Install additional software and or make additional updates to the endpoint device o  Upon request  Subject to security approval Include and manage o  NUIT’ service automated software updating services (Kace/ JAMF)  Endpoint security software(Symantec Endpoint Protection)  Whole disk encryption (MBAM and FileVault) Ensure desired work space has functional electrical and network access o  Make recommendations for electrical or network access and advise CONDUITS and FM ordering processes. Purchase, deliver and install workstation in desired work space o Troubleshooting wired or wireless network connectivity users, escalating to TNS has required. o • Address user observed errors upon notification Conduct troubleshooting and remediation efforts o Coordinate warranty work as required o  Coordinate with Dell, Lenovo/CDWG for services (PCs)  Coordinate with Apple service technician (MACs) Provide temporary loaner computer o  Upon request  If operationally necessary  Subject to availability Conference room and classroom support o  Coordinate with Northwestern IT Audio/Visual team as need for support issue • Provide departmental fiscal office with semi-annual refresh notifications for workstations. • Assist with providing purchasing recommendations for new or replacement computers • Provide major OS updates as required for vendor support (e.g. Windows “Creator Updates”, MacOS 10.X point releases) • Provide disposition of end-of-life devices Scrub data and remove hard drive o Send devices to Northwestern University Surplus and/or donate to Student Enrichment Services Mobile Devices The following support is offered upon request: • Make purchasing recommendations for Northwestern University owned mobile device • Configure mobile devise • Configure email • Coordinate activities with 3rd party vendors as required (University owned devices only) • Address user observed errors upon notification Conduct troubleshooting and remediation efforts o Coordinate warranty work as required (University owned devices only) o Printers The following support is offered upon request: • Set up printers • Organize for disposal of printers OU Administration (CampusAD) The following support is offered upon request: • Add new users to CampusAD • Create CampusAD accounts • Grant access to resources control via CampusAD • Delete users • Manage Group Policies Endpoint Management Services Management of the following endpoint management software’s: • Workstations will be patched no less than monthly for OS and application by use of management software, including Kace, JAMF • Full system backup of device including local machine stored data using Crashplan Monitoring of backup services will be provided, with either tickets generated o or user notification provided in the event that backups are not functioning Box The following support is offered upon request: • Install Box client software, such as Box Edit, Drive and Sync • Facilitate the creation of organization shares and group accounts Multi-function devices The following support is offered upon request: • Configure printing and scanning access to a multi-function device. • Address user observed errors upon notification Conduct troubleshooting and remediation efforts o Coordinate warranty work as required o Installation and Troubleshooting of customer specific software The following support is offered upon request: • Northwestern IT will install all customer specific software and will work with the user/experts in said software to ensure that the installation of these applications does not destabilize other desktop or application functionality • NUIT will work with the user/experts to contact the vendor of said software to accomplish same, but will not act independently of the user/experts in contacting vendors. Out of Scope The following services are explicitly not offered in this SLA. • Management of personal devices • Support for unmanaged devices such as servers, customer purchased devices New Technology Both Northwestern IT and the customer recognize that new technology adoption is important to the mission of the university. The customer may be introduced or considered for adoption during the course of this Agreement. At the mutual agreement of the NUIT and the customer, joint testing, demonstration, or evaluation of such technology may be undertaken. If the customer adopts a new computing technology and desires that NUIT support it, then the Customer Contact will consult with the TSS. If they agree that the new technology has a limited effect on support time for the support personnel, then it will be incorporated into the current support activities. Otherwise, the Customer Contact will follow the procedure described in the section entitled “Support Outside of this Agreement”. Computer Support Policies Northwestern IT will support the University-owned computers of the customer based on the following policies: 1. New purchases must meet the Northwestern IT recommended standards. New purchases will be set up with the NUIT software image. 2. Existing computer hardware must meet the minimum hardware and operating system standards. 3. Support level will be determined by the age of the machine Computer Age Support level Support description 0-4 years Full Support Northwestern IT will ensure the working order of the computer, using reasonable staff time and support resources 4-5 years Best Effort Northwestern IT will spend up to one hour fixing an issue. If the issue cannot be resolved at that time, NUIT will recommend replacing the computer and facilitate the recovery/transfer of data. 5 years or Out of Support Northwestern IT will facilitate the recovery/transfer of older data, but will not attempt to resolve technical issues. Legacy Computers connected to instruments • Best effort support will be provided to computers connected to research equipment in consultation with Northwestern IT’s Information Security Office • Legacy equipment may need to be placed off network to avoid remote exploit or other risk
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring the identified weaknesses in this clause presents significant operational and financial risks for the customer. The stringent age-based support policies, particularly the one-hour limit for 'Best Effort' and complete lack of technical issue resolution for devices over five years, could lead to unexpected and premature hardware replacement costs, extended downtime for critical functions reliant on older equipment, and potential data loss if issues cannot be resolved. The discretionary nature of support for new technologies, requiring 'mutual agreement' and NUIT's sole determination of support feasibility, creates uncertainty and could hinder the adoption of beneficial innovations, impacting productivity and competitiveness. Furthermore, the broad 'Out of Scope' services and various conditions for support (e.g., security approval for software, case-by-case assessment for dual-booting) introduce ambiguity and potential for disputes, leaving the customer vulnerable to service limitations or non-support, which could lead to operational inefficiencies and increased reliance on unmanaged or unsupported systems, posing security vulnerabilities.
results.suggested_correction: The following list specifies responsibilities of NUIT related to providing the service set forth in this agreement. Northwestern IT will be responsible for the following: Workstations (desktop and laptop computers) Build workstations Install one of NUIT approved computer images Support for dual booting or machines with multiple operating systems shall be assessed and approved by the Technology Support Services Director on a case by case basis, based on documented business, research or teaching need. Install additional software and or make additional updates to the endpoint device upon request, subject to NUIT's standard security approval processes. Include and manage NUIT’ service automated software updating services (Kace/ JAMF) Endpoint security software (Symantec Endpoint Protection) Whole disk encryption (MBAM and FileVault) Ensure desired work space has functional electrical and network access Make recommendations for electrical or network access and advise CONDUITS and FM ordering processes. Purchase, deliver and install workstation in desired work space Troubleshooting wired or wireless network connectivity users, escalating to TNS has required. Address user observed errors upon notification Conduct troubleshooting and remediation efforts Coordinate warranty work as required Coordinate with Dell, Lenovo/CDWG for services (PCs) Coordinate with Apple service technician (MACs) Provide temporary loaner computer upon request, if operationally necessary, and subject to availability. Conference room and classroom support Coordinate with Northwestern IT Audio/Visual team as need for support issue Provide departmental fiscal office with semi-annual refresh notifications for workstations. Assist with providing purchasing recommendations for new or replacement computers Provide major OS updates as required for vendor support (e.g. Windows “Creator Updates”, MacOS 10.X point releases) Provide disposition of end-of-life devices Scrub data and remove hard drive Send devices to Northwestern University Surplus and/or donate to Student Enrichment Services Mobile Devices The following support is offered upon request: Make purchasing recommendations for Northwestern University owned mobile device Configure mobile devise Configure email Coordinate activities with 3rd party vendors as required (University owned devices only) Address user observed errors upon notification Conduct troubleshooting and remediation efforts Coordinate warranty work as required (University owned devices only) Printers The following support is offered upon request: Set up printers Organize for disposal of printers OU Administration (CampusAD) The following support is offered upon request: Add new users to CampusAD Create CampusAD accounts Grant access to resources control via CampusAD Delete users Manage Group Policies Endpoint Management Services Management of the following endpoint management software’s: Workstations will be patched no less than monthly for OS and application by use of management software, including Kace, JAMF Full system backup of device including local machine stored data using Crashplan Monitoring of backup services will be provided, with either tickets generated or user notification provided in the event that backups are not functioning Box The following support is offered upon request: Install Box client software, such as Box Edit, Drive and Sync Facilitate the creation of organization shares and group accounts Multi-function devices The following support is offered upon request: Configure printing and scanning access to a multi-function device. Address user observed errors upon notification Conduct troubleshooting and remediation efforts Coordinate warranty work as required Installation and Troubleshooting of customer specific software The following support is offered upon request: Northwestern IT will install all customer specific software and will work with the user/experts in said software to ensure that the installation of these applications does not destabilize other desktop or application functionality NUIT will work with the user/experts to contact the vendor of said software to accomplish same, but will not act independently of the user/experts in contacting vendors. Out of Scope The following services are explicitly not offered in this SLA. Management of personal devices Support for unmanaged devices such as servers, customer purchased devices New Technology Both Northwestern IT and the customer recognize that new technology adoption is important to the mission of the university. The customer may introduce or consider new technology for adoption during the course of this Agreement. NUIT and the customer shall collaborate to assess new technologies. If the customer adopts a new computing technology and desires NUIT support, the Customer Contact shall consult with the TSS to determine support feasibility. If the TSS agrees that the new technology has a limited effect on support time for NUIT personnel, NUIT shall incorporate it into the current support activities. Otherwise, NUIT and the Customer Contact shall jointly define the scope and terms of support, which may require a separate agreement or amendment. Computer Support Policies Northwestern IT will support the University-owned computers of the customer based on the following policies: 1. New purchases must meet the Northwestern IT recommended standards. New purchases will be set up with the NUIT software image. 2. Existing computer hardware must meet the minimum hardware and operating system standards. 3. Support level will be determined by the age of the machine Computer Age Support level Support description 0-4 years Full Support Northwestern IT will ensure the working order of the computer, using reasonable staff time and support resources 4-5 years Best Effort Northwestern IT shall provide reasonable best efforts support. If the issue cannot be resolved through such efforts, NUIT shall recommend replacing the computer and facilitate the recovery/transfer of data. 5 years or Out of Support Northwestern IT shall facilitate the recovery/transfer of data and advise on replacement options. NUIT shall not be obligated to resolve technical issues for devices beyond vendor-supported lifecycles, except for critical security updates as deemed necessary by NUIT's Information Security Office. Legacy Computers connected to instruments Best effort support will be provided to computers connected to research equipment in consultation with Northwestern IT’s Information Security Office Legacy equipment may need to be placed off network to avoid remote exploit or other risk
results.justification: This clause, while extensively detailing the services Northwestern IT provides, contains numerous significant limitations, discretionary approvals, and explicit exclusions that create an imbalanced allocation of risk, heavily favoring NUIT and transferring substantial operational and financial exposure to the customer. Key enforceability risks stem from the age-based support policies: the 'Best Effort' support for 4-5 year old computers is severely limited to a one-hour fix, after which NUIT's obligation is to recommend replacement. More critically, for computers five years or older, NUIT 'will not attempt to resolve technical issues' at all, rendering critical equipment potentially unsupported without recourse. This introduces high commercial exposure for the customer, who may face unexpected costs for premature hardware replacement and significant operational downtime if essential equipment fails and cannot be repaired. The 'New Technology' section further compounds this by making NUIT's support entirely contingent on 'mutual agreement' and NUIT's unilateral assessment of 'limited effect on support time,' which can delay or prevent the adoption of vital innovations. Discretionary clauses, such as 'subject to security approval' for software installation and 'case by case basis' approval for dual-booting, introduce additional hurdles and potential for service delays or denials without clear, objective criteria. The extensive list of 'Out of Scope' services further defines the boundaries of NUIT's responsibilities, but when combined with the severe limitations on in-scope services, it underscores the customer's vulnerability. The cumulative effect of these provisions creates significant enforceability gaps and an imbalance of obligations, leading to a high-risk score of 7.0. The clause, as drafted, provides NUIT with considerable flexibility to limit its liabilities while placing the burden of managing aging infrastructure and adopting new technologies largely on the customer.

results.clause_text: The following list contains the customer’s responsibilities related to their use of this service: General • Submit requests for services to the IT Support Center (by email, phone, or self-service ticket entry) • Submit notification of service interruptions or reductions to the IT Support Center • Provide funding for the purchase of any equipment covered by this SLA • Provide a list of the devices and their serial numbers for each device covered by this SLA: Initial list will be provided from Kace export o Updates and changes to support environment will be managed in Kace, or its replacement for asset management o • Notify NUIT of devices to be added to the SLA throughout the year through the new computer request form Workstations • Arrange to refresh workstations within four years of purchase • Provide funding for the refresh purchase Printers • Purchase a service warranty for each University owned printer that includes break-fix and full replacement
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring the current drafting will leave the customer exposed to significant financial and operational burdens that are unilaterally imposed. This includes unbudgeted costs for equipment, workstation refreshes, and printer warranties, which can lead to financial strain or disputes if the customer cannot meet these obligations. The operational requirements for notifications, asset management updates, and workstation refreshes further place a heavy, explicit burden on the customer, potentially leading to service degradation or compliance issues if not managed diligently. The provider, while seemingly benefiting from this offloading of responsibility, may face customer dissatisfaction and operational friction if the customer struggles to uphold these extensive and often costly duties.
results.suggested_correction: The Customer shall be responsible for the following in relation to its use of the service: (a) submitting requests for services to the IT Support Center (by email, phone, or self-service ticket entry); (b) submitting notification of service interruptions or reductions to the IT Support Center; (c) providing funding for the purchase of any equipment covered by this SLA; (d) providing an initial list of devices and their serial numbers for each device covered by this SLA, which initial list will be derived from a Kace export, and ensuring updates and changes to the support environment are managed in Kace, or its designated replacement for asset management; and (e) notifying NUIT of devices to be added to the SLA throughout the year through the new computer request form. With respect to Workstations, the Customer shall arrange for the refresh of workstations within four years of purchase and shall provide funding for such refresh purchase. With respect to Printers, the Customer shall purchase a service warranty for each University-owned printer that includes break-fix and full replacement.
results.justification: This clause clearly defines party responsibilities related to service performance, specifically detailing extensive customer obligations, thereby classifying it as a 'Scope of Services' clause. The clause explicitly places numerous operational and significant financial responsibilities solely on the customer, including providing funding for equipment purchases, workstation refreshes, and service warranties for printers. While the clarity of these assignments benefits the provider by delineating the customer's duties, the clause creates a substantial commercial and operational risk for the customer due to the breadth and financial implications of these unilateral obligations. The clause is significantly imbalanced as it exclusively lists the customer's duties without outlining reciprocal responsibilities of the service provider within the same section. This imbalance, coupled with the substantial financial exposure for the customer, constitutes a significant contractual risk. The high risk score of 7.0 is justified by the presence of significant enforceability gaps or imbalance inherent in a clause that places such extensive and potentially costly responsibilities on one party without commensurate or balancing obligations within its scope, leading to high financial and operational exposure for the customer.

results.clause_text: This service agreement assumes the following: • NUIT will bill Customer for support activity outside of the scope of this agreement at a standard service rate • Overtime work will be charged at 150% of the standard rate • After hours support work that requires support personal to return to work will include a minimum charge of three hours
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring this clause's weaknesses presents significant commercial and operational risks. The lack of a defined 'standard service rate' creates financial uncertainty, potentially exposing the customer to unpredictable and escalating costs for out-of-scope, overtime, or after-hours work. Ambiguity surrounding what constitutes 'support activity outside of the scope of this agreement', 'overtime work', and 'after-hours support work' can lead to frequent disputes, erode trust, and strain the business relationship. The mandated minimum charge for after-hours support could result in disproportionately high costs for minor issues, further increasing the customer's financial burden and dissatisfaction. These factors combine to create a significant risk of uncontrolled expenditure and potential legal challenges over billing discrepancies.
results.suggested_correction: NUIT shall bill Customer for support activity performed outside the defined scope of this Agreement at NUIT's then-current standard service rates. Overtime work shall be charged at 150% of NUIT's then-current standard service rates. After-hours support work that requires NUIT personnel to return to work shall include a minimum charge of three hours.
results.justification: This clause establishes the framework for billing out-of-scope and premium services, thus fitting the classification of 'Payment Terms'. The primary enforceability risk stems from the lack of definition for critical terms. The 'standard service rate' is mentioned but not specified, creating a fundamental ambiguity regarding the actual cost of services. Similarly, 'support activity outside of the scope of this agreement' relies entirely on a well-defined scope elsewhere in the agreement; without this clarity, it becomes a significant source of dispute regarding what services are chargeable. The commercial exposure for the customer is substantial, as they could face unexpected and potentially exorbitant charges for services, particularly with the 150% overtime rate and the three-hour minimum for after-hours support. This minimum charge, in particular, can lead to disproportionate costs for minor service interventions. The clause is unbalanced because it unilaterally imposes additional charging mechanisms that benefit the provider by ensuring compensation for extra work, while simultaneously creating unforeseen and potentially high costs for the customer without corresponding mechanisms for cost control or clear service level agreements tied to these premium charges. The risk score of 6.5 reflects these significant enforceability gaps and the clear imbalance of obligations, leading to moderate but material financial and operational exposure for the customer.

results.clause_text: Support tickets, pertaining to service incidents (break-fix) and requests, should be submitted via the NUIT Service Desk and include the following information: • Customer contact information including: name, phone number, email address • Brief description of the service issue • Priority level of the incident or request The Service Desk staff will provide first level support to resolve the issue. Issues that are not resolved at first level will be escalated to Tier 2 support teams for resolution. Telephone calls received by the Service Desk outside of scheduled support hours will prompt callers to leave a message or page support staff for emergencies. The voice messages will be responded to on next business day. Customers are encouraged to check the NUIT Service Status web site https://service-status.northwestern.edu/ for scheduled maintenance events and service alerts. Hours Contact Information Days of operation Monday – 8:00 AM – 6:00 PM Phone: (847) 491-4357 Friday (1-HELP) Service Desk https://www.it.northwestern.edu/supportcenter/index.html Saturday Not Available Sunday Not Available Summer Hours Monday – Friday 8:00 am – 5:00pm CLOSED: Winter/Spring Break, University holidays
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring the current clause's deficiencies exposes the customer to significant operational and commercial risks. Without measurable key performance indicators (KPIs) for incident response and resolution times, particularly for high-priority issues, the customer has limited contractual leverage to ensure timely service restoration or issue resolution. The absence of defined remedies or service credits means the customer bears the full impact of service failures, including potential operational downtime, reputational damage, and increased internal costs to manage unresolved issues, without recourse. The reliance on the customer to proactively check for service alerts also places an undue burden and risk on the customer for awareness of critical service events, potentially delaying their response to outages or maintenance.
results.suggested_correction: Customer support requests and service incident (break-fix) reports shall be submitted via the NUIT Service Desk, including: Customer contact information (name, phone number, email address), a brief description of the issue, and the priority level. The Service Desk staff shall provide first-level support to resolve issues, with issues unresolved at first level being escalated to Tier 2 support teams for resolution. Response and resolution times for submitted incidents and requests shall be commensurate with their assigned priority level. Telephone calls received by the Service Desk outside of scheduled support hours will prompt callers to leave a message or page support staff for emergencies. Voice messages shall be responded to on the next business day. NUIT shall provide proactive notification of scheduled maintenance events and service alerts. The Service Desk operates Monday to Friday, 8:00 AM – 6:00 PM (Summer Hours: 8:00 AM – 5:00 PM, excluding Winter/Spring Break and University holidays). Contact may be made via phone at (847) 491-4357 (1-HELP) or via the Service Desk website at https://www.it.northwestern.edu/supportcenter/index.html.
results.justification: This clause is properly classified as a 'Service Levels' clause as it delineates the process for support requests, tiered escalation, and crucial operational hours, which are fundamental components of service availability and performance commitments. While it establishes a process, the clause contains significant enforceability gaps and creates an imbalance of obligations, warranting a high-risk assessment. Specifically, it critically lacks specific, measurable Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for response and resolution times across different incident types and priority levels. This absence means that while a process is described, there are no concrete, enforceable performance standards for the provider, shifting performance risk predominantly to the client. Furthermore, the clause fails to define any remedies or service credits for non-compliance with the stated support processes or for unmet service expectations, leaving the client without contractual recourse for service failures. The only specific time commitment is an implicit 'next business day' response for off-hours voicemails, which is insufficient for a comprehensive service level agreement covering various incident severities. The encouragement for customers to proactively check a separate website for maintenance and alerts further places the burden of critical information gathering on the customer, rather than a proactive notification obligation on the provider. These combined weaknesses result in an agreement that outlines operational procedures but lacks the contractual rigor to ensure specific service performance, leading to significant commercial exposure and potential operational disruption for the client if support is inadequate or untimely. The score of 7.0 reflects these significant enforceability gaps and the high operational and commercial exposure for the client due to the absence of measurable performance commitments and associated remedies.

results.clause_text: All incident tickets are assessed for customer impact and urgency to determine priority. A predefined Incident priority matrix is used as guidance in assessing incident priority. Priority Target Target Response Resolution Time Time Critical Immediate 2 Hour (P1) High 15 Minutes 8 Hours (P2) Medium 15 Minutes 24 Hours (P3) Low 4 Business 3 Business Days (P4) Hours NUIT aims to meet these targets 80% or more over a period of calendar month. ** We expect to provide a 15-minute response time and 2-hour target resolution time for all incidents or requests received from deans, director and chairs, and their designated assistants with a 90% of higher compliance target.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring this risk means accepting a service agreement where the stated performance levels are largely aspirational and non-binding. The client would be commercially exposed to potential service degradation, delayed incident resolution, and operational disruptions without any contractual recourse. This can lead to increased downtime, user dissatisfaction, and reputational damage if internal stakeholders perceive IT services as unreliable. Furthermore, the preferential treatment for specific high-level individuals, while potentially a positive relationship management strategy, could lead to resource strain and internal perception of unfairness if not managed carefully, but the primary risk remains the provider's lack of binding commitment to overall service levels, leaving the client vulnerable to unmet expectations without legal leverage.
results.suggested_correction: All incident tickets are assessed for customer impact and urgency to determine priority. A predefined Incident priority matrix is used as guidance in assessing incident priority. Priority Target Response Time Target Resolution Time Critical Immediate 2 Hour (P1) High 15 Minutes 8 Hours (P2) Medium 15 Minutes 24 Hours (P3) Low 4 Business Hours 3 Business Days. NUIT shall meet these targets at least 80% over a calendar month. NUIT shall also provide a 15-minute response time and 2-hour target resolution time for all incidents or requests received from deans, directors, and chairs, and their designated assistants, with at least 90% compliance over a calendar month.
results.justification: This clause defines measurable performance standards for incident response and resolution, classifying it as a Service Levels clause. However, it presents significant legal and commercial risks primarily due to the non-binding nature of its commitments. The use of aspirational language such as 'aims to meet' and 'we expect to provide' does not create a legally enforceable obligation on the part of the provider. Without clear, operative language like 'shall' or 'will,' these statements merely express an intention rather than a contractual commitment, rendering the service levels largely unenforceable. This enforceability gap is compounded by the complete absence of any remedies, service credits, or consequences for the provider's failure to meet these stated targets. From a client's perspective, this means there is no contractual leverage to ensure performance, leaving them exposed to service failures without recourse. While the clause outlines different priority levels and specific, more stringent targets for high-level individuals, these too suffer from the same aspirational language ('expect to provide'), diluting their binding effect. This creates a significant imbalance of obligations, as the client implicitly relies on these service levels, but the provider is not legally bound to deliver them, thereby exposing the client to substantial operational and commercial risks without corresponding contractual protection. The reconciled risk score of 7.0 reflects this significant enforceability gap and the high commercial exposure resulting from a lack of binding commitments and remedies for non-performance.

results.clause_text: Request Priority Response Time Resolution Time High 1 Business Hour 1 Business day Medium, 4 Business Hours 3 Business days Low 8 Business Hours 5 Business days NUIT aims to meet these targets 80% or more over a period of calendar month.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: The primary business risk is that the client cannot legally enforce the stated service level targets. The language 'NUIT aims to meet these targets' transforms what appears to be a binding commitment into an aspirational goal, effectively making the service levels a 'best effort' undertaking. This means that despite clear expectations for response and resolution times, the service provider has no firm contractual obligation to deliver them, even for 80% of requests. This lack of enforceability leads to significant operational exposure, as the client cannot hold the provider accountable for potential service failures or delays, impacting business continuity and customer satisfaction, without any contractual recourse or ability to claim damages for unmet expectations.
results.suggested_correction: NUIT shall ensure that, for at least 80% of all requests over a calendar month period, the following service levels are met: High Priority requests shall have a Response Time of 1 Business Hour and a Resolution Time of 1 Business Day; Medium Priority requests shall have a Response Time of 4 Business Hours and a Resolution Time of 3 Business Days; and Low Priority requests shall have a Response Time of 8 Business Hours and a Resolution Time of 5 Business Days.
results.justification: This clause defines specific, measurable performance standards for service requests, including response and resolution times categorized by priority, and establishes a compliance target of 80% over a calendar month. This aligns precisely with a Service Levels clause. However, the clause contains a significant legal flaw through the use of aspirational language, 'NUIT aims to meet these targets.' This phrasing fundamentally undermines the enforceability of the service level targets, converting what should be a firm contractual obligation into a mere statement of intent. For a legally robust service level agreement, the provider must unequivocally 'shall meet' or 'will ensure' such targets. The current drafting creates a substantial enforceability gap, as the client would struggle to claim breach of contract for missed targets. Furthermore, the clause lacks any specified remedies or service credits for failure to achieve even these 'aims,' exacerbating the commercial risk. While the targets themselves are clear, the absence of a firm commitment transforms them into non-binding aspirations, creating a significant imbalance of obligations where the provider has flexibility and the client has no contractual guarantees. This results in a high risk of commercial exposure for the client due to unreliable service delivery without recourse, justifying a high risk score.

results.clause_text: NUIT Service Desk function will aim to meet the following target conditions for key performance metrics. • 80% of calls answered or abandoned within 30 seconds (Service Level) Average • Speed of Answer: 30 seconds or less • Abandon Rate: 5-8% • First call resolution rate: 65% • Customer satisfaction rate: 85%
results.business_risk_if_ignored: If this clause remains uncorrected, its aspirational language ('will aim to meet') renders the stated performance targets non-binding. This fundamental drafting weakness means the service provider has no legally enforceable obligation to achieve these metrics. Consequently, the client cannot claim a breach of contract, compel performance, or seek remedies such as service credits or damages if the service desk consistently underperforms or fails to meet these 'aims'. The commercial exposure for the client is substantial; they bear all the operational and financial risk associated with potential service degradation, including disruptions to their own operations, reduced end-user satisfaction, and potential reputational damage, all without any contractual recourse to hold the provider accountable for failing to deliver the expected level of service.
results.suggested_correction: The NUIT Service Desk function shall meet the following Service Level targets for key performance metrics: 80% of calls shall be answered or abandoned within 30 seconds; the Average Speed of Answer shall be 30 seconds or less; the Abandon Rate shall not exceed 8%; the First Call Resolution Rate shall be 65%; and the Customer Satisfaction Rate shall be 85%.
results.justification: This clause, while accurately categorized as a Service Levels clause, presents significant enforceability gaps and creates a material imbalance of obligations. The core issue lies in the aspirational language, 'will aim to meet,' which undermines the binding nature of the performance targets. Instead of establishing a firm commitment, this phrasing transforms the metrics into goals rather than contractual obligations, making it exceptionally difficult for the client to enforce performance or claim breach if targets are not achieved. Compounding this, the clause entirely omits any provisions for remedies, service credits, or consequences for underperformance. This absence places all performance risk squarely on the client, as there is no contractual mechanism to hold the provider accountable or to compensate the client for the operational and commercial impact of unmet service levels. The combination of non-binding commitments and a complete lack of recourse constitutes a high level of commercial exposure and an inherent imbalance, warranting a significant risk score. The risk score of 7.5 reflects these substantial enforceability gaps and the direct commercial consequences for the client arising from the lack of contractual leverage.

results.clause_text: In the event of an ongoing service level breach, NUIT will perform a root cause analysis and present options to review and determine appropriate steps to mitigate, which could include increasing staffing levels, process adjustments, or other remediation steps.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: The client faces significant operational and financial exposure. Without clear timelines for root cause analysis, presenting options, and implementing determined mitigation steps, an ongoing service level breach could persist indefinitely, leading to prolonged disruption. The lack of an explicit obligation for NUIT to implement the agreed-upon remediation and bear its cost could shift the burden and expense to the client, or result in no effective resolution at all. This absence of clear enforceability for NUIT's resolution actions means the client lacks contractual leverage to compel timely and effective remediation, potentially incurring sustained losses and reputational damage due to the underlying service failure.
results.suggested_correction: In the event of an ongoing service level breach, NUIT shall promptly perform a root cause analysis and, following its completion, NUIT shall promptly present to Client options and proposed steps to mitigate the breach. NUIT and Client shall then promptly review and mutually agree upon the appropriate steps. NUIT shall diligently implement the agreed-upon steps at NUIT’s cost, which may include increasing staffing levels, process adjustments, or other remediation steps.
results.justification: This clause, pertaining to service levels, obligates the provider (NUIT) to perform a root cause analysis and present mitigation options following an ongoing service level breach, which are positive initial steps. However, it exhibits significant enforceability gaps and an imbalance of obligations, leading to a moderate risk assessment. The clause lacks specified timelines for the completion of the root cause analysis, the presentation of options, or the subsequent implementation of any determined mitigation steps, which can allow an ongoing breach to continue without a clear path to resolution. Critically, while NUIT is to 'present options to review and determine appropriate steps,' there is no explicit contractual commitment for NUIT to actually implement the determined steps, nor is there clarity on who bears the cost of such implementation. The ambiguity surrounding the decision-making process and the absence of a firm obligation for NUIT to act decisively on agreed solutions place an undue burden on the client and weaken the client's ability to compel effective remediation. Furthermore, the clause provides no consequences, such as service credits or penalties, for the ongoing breach itself or for NUIT's failure to timely or effectively resolve it. This combination of omissions in timelines, implementation obligations, cost allocation, and consequences creates significant commercial exposure for the client, as they may suffer prolonged service disruption and associated losses without adequate contractual recourse, justifying a risk score of 6.0.

results.clause_text: During periods of multiple simultaneous service requests, NUIT will allocate resources in accordance with the following criteria: 1. High impact services (Mission Critical) 2. High volume services 3. Production services (opposed to training, quality assurance, test, development) 4. Time sensitive services 5. Other services
results.business_risk_if_ignored: If this clause remains uncorrected, NUIT faces significant commercial exposure and potential for disputes. The broad and undefined 'Other services' category places any unclassified client service at the lowest priority during peak demand, inevitably leading to substantial delays, unmet expectations, and negative business impact for those clients. This unilateral prioritization, combined with potential ambiguity in defining 'high impact,' 'high volume,' or 'time sensitive' services, can erode client trust, result in dissatisfaction, and could lead to claims of breach of service expectations, even if not explicitly defined elsewhere. NUIT's reputation for reliable service delivery would be at risk.
results.suggested_correction: During periods of multiple simultaneous service requests, NUIT shall allocate resources in accordance with the following criteria: 1. Mission Critical Services; 2. High Volume Services; 3. Production Services (excluding training, quality assurance, test, and development services); 4. Time Sensitive Services; 5. All other services not falling within criteria 1-4, which shall be prioritized following the preceding categories.
results.justification: This clause establishes a critical prioritization scheme for NUIT's resource allocation during periods of high demand, directly impacting service delivery and performance standards. While outlining an operational procedure, it fundamentally functions as a unilateral statement of service prioritization, carrying significant commercial implications. The clause presents a moderate risk primarily due to its inherent imbalance and potential for commercial exposure for certain services. Specifically, the definition of 'Other services' is overly broad, relegating any unclassified service to the lowest priority, which can lead to significant delays, unmet expectations, and business impact for clients whose services fall into this category during peak times. Although the prioritization criteria are listed, some lack precise definitions or quantifiable metrics, creating ambiguity that could lead to disputes regarding whether resources were allocated 'in accordance with' the stated criteria. The clause is drafted entirely from NUIT's perspective, without explicit mechanisms for client input or negotiation regarding service prioritization, which makes it unbalanced. This unilateral control over resource allocation, particularly for broadly defined lower-priority services, introduces a significant commercial risk for clients and justifies a risk score of 6.0.

results.clause_text: This Agreement represents the entire agreement between the customer and NUIT and supersedes all prior negotiations or agreements, written or oral, which are not included herein. This Agreement may only be amended by written instructions executed by the customer and NUIT. Either party may end this agreement by providing 90 days written notice. All customer assets, in the form of data or otherwise, related to this agreement must be obtained by the customer before or on the date of termination.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: If this clause is ignored, the customer faces a high risk of significant data loss and severe operational disruption upon termination. The current wording places an unrealistic and unilaterally burdensome obligation on the customer to retrieve all assets by the termination date, without clear corresponding duties for NUIT to facilitate this process or provide a reasonable grace period. This could prevent the customer from accessing critical business data, impacting business continuity, regulatory compliance, and potentially leading to substantial financial losses and reputational damage. Furthermore, the phrasing of the 'entire agreement' clause could lead to minor disputes regarding the inclusion or exclusion of prior agreements.
results.suggested_correction: This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the customer and NUIT and supersedes all prior negotiations or agreements, written or oral. This Agreement may only be amended by a written instrument signed by the customer and NUIT. Either party may terminate this Agreement by providing 90 days' prior written notice. Upon termination, NUIT shall make customer assets, in the form of data or otherwise, related to this Agreement available to the customer for retrieval for a period of thirty (30) days following the effective date of termination. The customer shall be responsible for retrieving all such assets within this period.
results.justification: The clause primarily covers the entire agreement, amendment procedures, and termination rights, with a significant portion dedicated to the conditions and obligations upon termination. The termination aspect, including the 90-day notice period, is balanced as it applies to either party. However, the provision regarding the retrieval of customer assets presents a substantial legal risk and commercial exposure. It places a strict, unilateral burden on the customer to retrieve all assets 'before or on the date of termination' without specifying NUIT's corresponding obligations to facilitate retrieval, outlining a clear retrieval mechanism, or allowing for any grace period post-termination. This creates a significant enforceability gap and an imbalance of obligations, as it could effectively leave the customer unable to retrieve critical data if NUIT does not cooperate or if the customer cannot meet the immediate deadline. Such an outcome could lead to severe operational disruption, data loss, and significant financial impact for the customer. While the entire agreement and amendment provisions are standard, the critical deficiency in the asset retrieval process elevates the overall risk. The score of 7.0 reflects this significant enforceability gap and the high commercial exposure stemming from potential data loss and operational disruption for the customer, placing it firmly in the 'High' risk category.

results.clause_text: Support under this agreement is recognized as a cooperative effort between customer, and Northwestern IT. The expertise Northwestern IT is providing is support for only the items outlined in this agreement. Should the customer determine there is a need for support for any items not specifically outlined in this agreement; the following procedure should be followed: A request should be made, in writing or in electronic form, to NUIT outlining the service requested. Note: requests for additional services should not be made to support personnel on site. Northwestern IT will create a proposal to deliver the service, detailing any new fees if incremental staff or services are required, and forward it to customer for review. Once approved by customer the proposal will be set forth as an addendum to this Agreement or as a new agreement if the requested services are foreign to the intentions of this Agreement.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring this clause would expose Northwestern IT to significant scope creep, leading to uncompensated provision of services and potential financial losses. The customer would face uncertainty regarding service inclusions, potentially leading to dissatisfaction if expected services are not delivered or are unexpectedly billed. Without a formal process, informal requests could lead to miscommunication, unapproved work, and disputes over service boundaries, fees, and resource allocation, ultimately harming the commercial relationship and operational efficiency for both parties.
results.suggested_correction: Northwestern IT shall provide support exclusively for the services and items expressly described in this Agreement. If Customer requires support for any services or items not expressly described herein, the following procedure shall apply: Customer shall submit a formal request, in writing or electronic form, to Northwestern IT, detailing the desired additional service. Customer shall not make requests for additional services to on-site support personnel. Northwestern IT shall then prepare and provide to Customer a proposal detailing the requested service, any new fees, and any incremental staff or resources required. Upon Customer's written approval, such proposal shall be formalized and incorporated into this Agreement by way of a mutually executed addendum, or, if the nature of the requested services is materially outside the scope and intent of this Agreement, by a new, separate agreement.
results.justification: This clause effectively defines the initial scope of services by explicitly limiting Northwestern IT's support to items outlined in the agreement. Crucially, it establishes a robust and formal change control process for any additional services beyond the defined scope. This process requires a written or electronic request from the customer, followed by Northwestern IT's proposal detailing new fees and resource requirements, customer review and approval, and formalization via a mutually executed addendum or a new agreement. This structured approach is a key mechanism for managing scope, preventing uncompensated work, and ensuring clarity for both parties regarding service expectations and associated costs. The instruction prohibiting informal requests to on-site personnel further reinforces scope control, mitigating the risk of scope creep or misunderstandings. While outlining a process for services not initially covered, the clause itself is balanced, as it protects both the service provider from unmanaged demands and the customer by providing a clear pathway for legitimate service expansion with transparent cost implications. The clause's clear definition of initial scope and its comprehensive change control procedure significantly mitigate common risks associated with service agreements, thereby justifying a low risk score. Any perceived risks are primarily managed by the procedural elements within the clause, which function as effective controls rather than weaknesses.

results.clause_text: Customer (Major Administration Unit): Fiscal Officer: Phone number: Email: Account: Sub Account:
results.justification: All models agree this clause is not a golden clause.

results.clause_text: The below cost model only applies if there is not an existing Memorandum of Understanding. If a signed MOU exists please refer to that for the cost of agreement. Workstations: $525/year Mobile Devices $525/year Printers: No Charge (Limit one printer per workstation) Multi-function Devices: No Charge (Limit one multi-function device per workstation) Devices added mid-year prorated based upon applicable annual service charge for device.
results.business_risk_if_ignored: Ignoring the identified weaknesses in this clause carries significant commercial exposure primarily related to revenue assurance and dispute resolution. The lack of clarity regarding the interplay between this cost model and a potential Memorandum of Understanding creates a substantial risk of invoicing disputes, administrative overhead in determining the correct applicable charges, and potential under- or over-billing. Crucially, the absence of specified invoicing triggers, payment due dates, and provisions for interest on delayed payments directly impacts cash flow and increases the administrative burden and costs associated with chasing overdue payments, potentially leading to prolonged payment cycles and impaired financial performance. Furthermore, the vague proration methodology for mid-year device additions invites disagreements over calculations, while the unenforceability of 'no charge' limits due to an undefined 'workstation' can lead to uncontrolled costs for the service provider, effectively offering unlimited free devices and eroding profitability.
results.suggested_correction: Unless a signed Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is in effect, the following cost model shall apply. Should a signed MOU exist, its provisions shall govern all costs for the agreement. Costs: Workstations: $525/year; Mobile Devices: $525/year; Printers: No Charge (limited to one printer per Workstation); Multi-function Devices: No Charge (limited to one multi-function device per Workstation). Devices added mid-year shall be prorated on a daily basis from the date of addition based upon the applicable annual service charge for such device. Invoices for services rendered under this cost model shall be issued annually in advance and are due for payment within thirty (30) days from the invoice date. Overdue amounts shall accrue interest at a rate of 1.5% per month or the maximum rate permitted by law, whichever is less. For the purposes of this clause, 'Workstation' means a desktop or laptop computer assigned to a named user.
results.justification: This clause, while defining specific device costs and a proration mechanism, presents significant enforceability gaps and creates an imbalance of obligations, warranting a risk score of 6.5. Its conditional applicability based on the existence of an external Memorandum of Understanding introduces administrative complexity and potential for conflict, as it lacks clear guidance on how to prioritize or reconcile differing cost structures if both documents are referenced without a definitive hierarchy. A major enforceability gap arises from the complete absence of fundamental payment terms: there are no specified invoicing triggers, payment due dates, or provisions for interest on delayed payments. This omission disproportionately disadvantages the service provider by leaving payment timelines open to interpretation and lacking remedies for late payment, directly affecting cash flow and operational certainty. Additionally, the proration methodology, while mentioned, is vaguely defined ('prorated based upon applicable annual service charge for device') and lacks the specificity (e.g., daily, monthly pro-rata) required to prevent disputes over calculations. Furthermore, the 'no charge' limits for printers and multi-function devices, which are tied to 'one per workstation', are rendered largely unenforceable without a clear and explicit definition of 'workstation' within the agreement, creating an exposure where the service provider might inadvertently provide unlimited free devices. These cumulative deficiencies lead to an agreement that is difficult to administer, prone to disputes, and creates a clear imbalance where the service provider's revenue collection is at risk, justifying a moderate risk rating approaching high due to the multiple critical omissions.

contract_text:
Service Level Agreement
and
Northwestern IT
Contents
1.0 Service Level Agreement Overview ................................................................................................... 3
2.0 Business Service Description ............................................................................................................. 3
3.0 Agreement Period .............................................................................................................................. 4
4.0 Maintenance ...................................................................................................................................... 4
5.0 Northwestern IT Responsibilities ....................................................................................................... 4
6.0 Customer Responsibilities .................................................................................................................. 8
7.0 Assumptions ...................................................................................................................................... 9
8.0 Requesting Support ........................................................................................................................... 9
8.1 Incident Response and Resolution Times.......................................................................................... 10
8.2 Service Request Response and Resolution Times .............................................................................. 10
8.4 Service Desk Metrics ........................................................................................................................ 11
8.6 Ongoing breach in service level ........................................................................................................ 11
9.0 Priority of service requests ............................................................................................................... 11
10.0 Amendments or Termination.......................................................................................................... 11
11.0 Support Outside of this Agreement ................................................................................................. 12
12.0 Billing Information ........................................................................................................................ 12
13.0 Cost of Agreement ..................................................................................................................................... 12
1.0 Service Level Agreement Overview
This document is a Service Level Agreement between Northwestern IT (service provider)
and the (customer), outlining the provisioning of IT services.
The purpose of this agreement is to establish service expectations, identify provider and
consumer responsibilities related to this service, specify how this service is supported, and
clarify service charges.
2.0 Business Service Description
Northwestern IT (NUIT) agrees to provide Endpoint device management and support as a
service to customer.
NUIT will: provide
• Device deployment – Procurement, Custom factory image loading including
enterprise licensed common applications, asset tagging and labelling, pre-delivery
and staging services, and system installation, system configuration and data
migrations. Delivers and installs your fully integrated systems to customer
designated user locations.
• Secure endpoint management - pre-configuration of security solutions and
installation of antivirus, data encryption and data backup solutions. Regular
application of Operating system and application software patches.
• Device Management - Agent monitoring to ensure proper tracking of device
lifecycle
• NUIT Service Desk - represents the entry point and first-touch support process for
all hardware and software service-related requests. NUIT delivers a strategic,
customized full-featured service desk that is driven by the goals of quality, value,
and customer satisfaction. NUIT service desk is accountable to resolve, track,
escalate and follow-up on all Endpoint systems related issues that affect customer
productivity.
• NUIT provides on-site Field Services support for endpoint systems, software, and
peripherals support. We assist with installations, moves, adds and changes, as well
as everyday hardware and peripheral support services.
Authorized service delivery providers will be dispatched to your End User when
hardware, software, or peripheral problems cannot be resolved remotely.
• Disposition and redeployment– NUIT delivers efficient, secure and simple
processes for data recoveries to disposals and refreshes. Ensures that system data
is destroyed for security purposes. Disposal of Assets and manages Employee
Purchase Programs.
3.0 Agreement Period
The period of this agreement is September 1, 2019 through August 30, 2020. Each year,
this agreement will automatically extend for one calendar year unless it is modified or
terminated as described in this document.
4.0 Maintenance
Maintenance of services provided in this agreement will be conducted in accordance with
established NUIT Change Management practices, and will occur during scheduled service
maintenance windows. Emergency maintenance, in response to service outages, may
occur with no advanced notice to service consumers. Maintenance or outages of other,
underlying or integrated, services may impact the services provided in this agreement.
Notification of service maintenance and outages is available at:
Service Status (https://service-status.northwestern.edu/).
Information on how to subscribe to email service alerts can be found at:
https://service-status.northwestern.edu/
5.0 Northwestern IT Responsibilities
The following list specifies responsibilities of NUIT related to providing the service set
forth in this agreement. Northwestern IT will be responsible for the following:
Workstations (desktop and laptop computers)
• Build workstations
Install one of NUIT approved computer images
o
 Dual booting or machines with multiple operating systems will be
assessed and approved by the Technology Support Services Director on
a case by case basis based on business, research or teaching need.
Install additional software and or make additional updates to the endpoint
o
device
 Upon request
 Subject to security approval
Include and manage
o
